course_title: Communication and Swallowing Across the Lifespan II

learning_outcomes.description: Apply foundational frameworks and principles to support ethical, person-centred, and evidence-informed adult speech pathology practice and advocacy. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.1, 1.6, 1.7, 2.5, 3.1)
Explain and apply key theories of language, speech processing, and cognition in adults to inform clinical reasoning and communication strategies. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 2.5, 3.1, 3.3)
Describe the components and functional implications of communication and swallowing in typically ageing adults. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 3.1, 3.2)

Describe key theoretical models and concepts related to adult communication and swallowing disorders, including aphasia, motor speech disorders, cognitive-communication impairments, and dysphagia, to support clinical reasoning. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 2.5)

Describe the professional role of a speech pathologist in adult settings, including responsibilities in advocacy, education, and interprofessional collaboration. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.4, 1.7, 3.1, 3.6)

Demonstrate professional and ethical written communication skills for public-facing and clinical contexts, with consideration for advocacy of the profession and the needs of adults with communication and swallowing impairments. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.5, 1.7, 3.1, 3.6)
Reflect on and apply learning related to communication and swallowing in adults to support professional growth and evidence-informed practice. (SPA PS Domains/Standards 2.1, 2.2, 2.5)
Work effectively in professional teams (SPA PS Domains/Standards 1.4, 2.3, 2.5, 2.6, 3.1, 3.3, 3.4).

assessments.task_description:
As part of Speech Pathology Week, students will create a 1–2 minute Instagram reel for the UQHealth social media account. The reel must promote the speech pathology profession or studying speech pathology at UQ and be tailored to an audience of current and prospective health students. The content must also align with the official theme of Speech Pathology Australia (SPA) Week and reflect the tone and values of the UQHealth brand.

Students will present their reels during tutorials in week 5. The multimedia and peer mark for the social media campaign are due by 4pm Monday 18th August, 2025 (Week 4).

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Reflective practice is a core component of the speech pathology profession and underpins excellence in speech pathology practice. Students are required to submit a series of Reflective Practice Statements. These reflections will be informed by participation in several simulated clinical encounters where students will practise skills regarding clinical reasoning, effective communication, lifelong learning, and professionalism. Students will attend the sessions in Weeks 6, 7, and 8. Absence from sessions in weeks 7 and 8 requires a medical certificate to be submitted to the Course Coordinator. Students will be allocated to simulation sessions based on tutorial allocations.

Students will complete a series of three (3) reflective practice statements on their skills, knowledge, and learning gained from the simulation sessions, which will count 15% (5% per reflection) towards the overall grade in this course. Prompt questions will be provided to guide the reflection. The reflection can be submitted in either video or written form.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

learning_activities.topic:
On-Campus Tutorials

The tutorials will be conducted from weeks 2-5 and weeks 9-12 of the semester and incorporate small group discussion to further explore communication and swallowing across the lifespan, and development of professional communication skills utilised with adults. Tutorials have been designed for experiential learning, therefore students are expected to attend and participate in all tutorials. Students must prepare for weekly tutorials by completing the online, self-directed learning modules and associated preparation activities and bringing this information to their tutorial ready to share. As students will be working small groups during tutorials, tutorials will not be recorded.
